title: If I report someone I do NOT want to be put in another game with them.... EVER.
body:
The title says it all. I had the most toxic support, in a ranked game, that held the team hostage by saying if we didn't give him farm he was going to feed. When the adc farmed a big minion wave he decided to stroll down midlane and let the other team kill him. I reported him along with several other members in the game. The very next game he is on my team again. He proceeded to verbally abuse the whole team and after he died he said he was going to afk or feed. He proceeded to sell all of his items for 5 tears. 

I don't care if I have to wait 15 mins in queue because all the people I have reported are trying to join games. DO NOT put someone in a game with some one they reported. They reported the person for a reason, part of that is they don't ever want to see their face again.

replies.body:
Hey El Don Juan,

We can all relate to the frustration that comes with being matched twice in a row with a rager.  While it may be possible to restrict players from playing with another they have reported, we're wary to do this because of how it could affect matchmaking.   In addition, we know that sometimes players may have a brief instance of toxicity where they deserve to be reported, but who quickly resume normal play style without incident; in these situations it doesn't always make sense to permanently black list them.

Instead, the PB team here has been looking at ways to improve the speed at which our disciplinary systems respond to player reports.  Ideally, the current system will act very quickly after a report has been sent.  For example, in your case I went ahead and did some digging and noticed that the player has been exited from the game for their transgressions.

With that said, the system is still relatively new, and there is a lot of tuning going on to increase the systems effectiveness.  Although it can be disheartning at times, you're doing the right thing by leaving a report on that player (as you did in this instance).  All reports are collected and sent to our system to better calibrate it for the future.

Surely you can implement something that puts them on a time clock, like you won't get matched with that player for like an hour.  Something  to ensure you don't get the same asshat the very next game, I'd imagine with a one game buffer people would feel better than getting that same toxic asshat in the next game when you are trying to move on from the previous disaster.

The most effective way to avoid running into the same player is leave queue for 5 mins, go to the bathroom, grab a drink, whatever, and then rejoin. If you have a game with a rager take a breather and go back into it. It doesn't help going into games mad just because other people are putting you on tilt. 

I played 3 ranked games a few hours ago...

First game we were winning hard and our Ashe was raging at our whole team, started feeding and we ended up losing.

Second game; I got the same guy from the last game who was playing Talon, came in said he was jungling and wouldn't gank any lanes because it wouldn't matter how far we were ahead, we would still lose (his words, not mine)..We still won, but the entire game he was sitting there encouraging the other team, pretty much trying to help them win, and bitching at anyone that would die on our team.

Third game; He was on the other team, raging in /All chat all game.

I decided that was enough of ranked after having to deal with him 3 games in a row.

While this works it shouldn't be on the person who was subject to someone else's bad behavior to fix things. Especially when the solution from Riot's end is so simple. They should put a time limit where after reporting anyone not on your friends list you can't be matched with them.

And to be clear it should be the person doing the reporting who has to wait longer in order to dodge that person (prevents abuse) but with an option to turn that feature off and let it pair you with people you recently reported.
I agree, except it's not that simple. In theory? Yes. In reality? No. People would find ways to abuse that "simple" system.
How? I'm pretty sure I put in the only two anti abuse systems you would need. If you can think of other problems please share them.

Also I've adopted the policy of only doing one ranked game per day so far I haven't had any toxic people on my team though i know that's just luck on my part. I know ranked works me up to much and I don't like having that much pressure on myself.

As League of Potato menitoned leaving queue briefly will allow you to avoid matching up with someone from your last game. Although it doesn't even have to be that overt. Generally even a 30 second delay before re-queueing is enough to get a completely new set of players. In fact I always do this just because it feels nice to start fresh, even if there were good players in the last game.

Thanks for the reply, the little message saying the guy had been punished definitely helped. As some people have said in this comment section, would a time delay be possible? May a few hours? A day? If I encountered someone on a different day who was toxic I probably wouldn't even remember unless they relapse into the same toxic patterns.

just make it so they don't appear in the next game. after that the two players will probably be desynced so they won't have a chance to appear in together in the next game. or at least one would hope. theres always a chance.

so what is the purose of having a BLOCK option, when in fact, it doesnt work, what exactly is the block option supposed to do, and why if someone AFK from ARAM, they are unreportable at the post game screen, the thumbs down option isnt available for only that player
To block messages and friend requests, like how any block option works.

im not worried about a FEEDER sending me friend requests or messages, but i AM worried about being paired up with him again so he can toxically feed again, so i figured BLOCKING someone would prevent me being put on the same team, or same game with him, but thanks for ur smart@$$ response

And this can be abused in ranked, players end up blocking everyone they deem bad and match making starts suffering heavily.

No need to be a dickhead over it, you asked and I answered the question.

matchmaking suffers? how? if anything it would just lengthen the queue time of the possibly toxic reporter it has no effect on anyone exept for bronze will now be temporary for those that do not belong there. after you block most of the toxic people you will only have games where its based only by skill rather than luck as it currently is.

*** edit:  also it would put those that repeat this offence without being seen by riots system will be queued with only thier own kind or have extremely long queues. this addition will only be a good thing

You need to have room for abuse, imagine everyone having the ability to completely block people entirely, once that gets around the queue times don't just get longer they flat out start pulling people from higher elos into your game because everyone kept getting rid of people.

It isn't about skill, it's get rid of anyone you deem bad.
could they have a mmr hard cap of who gets matched with you?
Nope that opens the possibility of jut not finding anyone at all.
and whos fault would that be? its the troll who got reported or blocked by everyone or the less often person who just blames everyone

You say less often but it would be common place, everyone in the game has a moment of weakness where they snap or just don't like one of there team mates, and the temptation to just remove them from any possible future games is WAAAY to tempting to refuse.

This is something that couldn't work out if it was permanent.
since its the common mindset for bronze and silver i guess it could be common but it would still work in the positive whether they do that or not

believe or not, it used to work this way and you could literally screw the matchmaking system with it. Season 1 you could report every player in every game, and you'd end up matched againt higher MMR players pretty quickly, making your MMR rise disproportionate to your skill as you would only need to win about 40% of your games to rise, maybe less. A real life friend found this out, actually got gold using it.
mmr hard cap would solve this

u was the dickhead first, u need to word ur sentences better to not come off like a jerk, where i come from a block means u wont get queued with the jerk again as well as never having to see him send friend requests or messages
Name 1 other matchmaking game where blocking someone does that.

well i used to think it was this game, until i went to block someone for being really bad and they was already blocked, but i dont play online pc games other than this, i come from xbox, so XBOX LIVE, (halo)
Okay yet you phrased it as if League is the only game to do blocking wrong, as will as calling me a smartass for stating the same thing.
That's nice dear.
I'm pretty sure the block option is just so you don't get friend requests and messages on the client from certain players, but I understand what you're saying.
I'd settle for just not having them on my team the following game... they can be on the enemy team if that makes things easier at the very highest and very lowest levels of ranked.

This is the first time ever I seen League breach their  -OH ALMIGHTY rule - of not letting us know whether someone was punished or not. Was it so hard Riot? Was it? Does anyone really care if you tell people that someone else was banned for being extremely toxic. I'm sure for him it was an amazing feeling just to know that the player was punished, but for the rest of us, we submit a ticket and get this token response that you can't let us know whether they were punished or not. Why not? YOU JUST DID IT HERE, why can't you do it elsewhere? Do I have to make a witty post that gets 90 upvotes for you to tell me everytime I run into someone like Don Juan did(btw which is a lot) for you to magically release info on whether they were punished or not?
I've seen it many times, but you need to calm down or you might hurt yourself.

hey woookie.
When can I mute myself? I'd really like to because I've been a salty bastard lately.

This reporting system just blows me away how horrible it is, to this day.  Not only are you matched with the same people you report for having bad behavior, but it takes a head-turning amount of reports and incidents of threats, trolling, rude, and otherwise bad behavior for someone to simply get a slap on the wrist.  Does no one at Riot believe in social justice?  I would love to permanently ban well over hundreds of people at this point for the things they have said in one game alone.  PERMANENT bans need to take place if they have been reported enough and CONFIRMED to have threatened or took the time to type out insult after insult after insult.  It's not just nerd rage that gets these guys going, it's just that they're bad people, or constantly make bad decisions, and letting them talk to the community and take part of it is out of question.  Either let people BLACKLIST, or come on the forums/submit a report ticket WITH THE SUMMONER'S NAME and log and hell even VIDEO of what happened, otherwise these people keep getting off scot-free.

First off, it would still affect it, which runs contrary to the principles of fair matchmaking.

The other problem is that it would dramatically increase wait times as the system scanned so that no one is playing with someone on their list. I have 60+ on mine.

Fair matchmaking isn't repeatedly pairing you with people who ruin your experience.  60+ people out of how many hundreds of thousands?  If my options are wait 20 minutes in queue because my block list is so large or play with some guy who has ruined a game with me before, sign me up for a 20 minute wait.  Don' make me have to dodge and possibly have to wait 30 minutes on top of LP losses to get away from that person.  The worst feeling ever is to get the same guy who just ruined 30 minutes of your time right back on your team again.  Sometimes even after you waited for a little while to queue back up.  It leads to another loss I'd wager at least 75% of the time based off my own experiences. 

 It's actually a rare occasion that I realize that i'm playing with someone I have blocked.  I actually haven't blocked anyone in a long time.  I just mute people in game.  Every now and then i'll be in a game and when it's over I'll notice they're already muted even though I didn't do it that game.  But if I didn't just block you but reported you also....there should be enough time between us getting paired together again that we at least possibly don't remember each other so there's no hard feelings.  We might even only remember playing with each other before vaguely and not how the match went.  But there should definitely be 50 games or so in between so they aren't even in my match history anymore.
I don't understand the mentality that says I should have to take a break because someone else was raging.

I had to support an APC Annie in a ranked game once. We lost, they blamed me. Whatever. I went to get a snack and a drink and requeued five minutes later.
Got the same APC Annie and had to support. I got blamed once again.

There was also a week where I met the same Tryndamere player multiple times, on my team and on the enemy team. His username was ridiculous which is why I remembered him.

So yes folks, it IS possible to get the same person despite waiting a little bit to queue.
Correct me if I'm wrong but you can put them in your block list. This would make them not able to message you, queue with you, etc. Unless this is Completely omitted when it comes to rank matchmaking
